Ian Badcoe wrote:

>	Inspired by Colin, I have been taking a bit of a look at TicTacToe, and 
>trying to build a system with some of my ideas for modularity built into it.
>  
>
>	To this end I have created something I'm calling SLEAT:
>
>		Symbolic Logic Evolution by Augmenting Topologies
>  
>
What you described sounds like EP, or at least what my poorly informed 
view of EP is. :)  By this I mean EP combines input values within a 
network (usually a tree I think) of operators to produce an output, or 
outputs (1 output per tree?). To me it seems that your functions are 
equivalent to one of these trees that map a load of inputs to an output...

>	This is very much work-in-progress,
>
Isn't everything?

>	OK, so the basic idea is to take the ideas behind Ken's "standard" NEAT 
>and add just enough new pieces to enable some modularity.  I also wanted to 
>build in some ability to exploit symmetry, but my first take on that didn't 
>pan out, so I've put that on hold for the moment.
>  
>
I wonder, have any of the modular NEAT experiments investigated 
exploitation of symmetry? So e.g. when attaching modules to the inputs 
(or each other) if you have knowledge that e.g. the inputs describe 
points on a 2D surface then you can attach to those inputs in various 
permutations of rotation, translation and reflection - instead of 
attempting random combinations.

>
>(i) by considering the input cells in terms of there geometric relationship 
>to one another, we can rephrase our original expression as:
>
>X = IsMine(LeftOf(B)) AND IsMine(RightOf(B)) AND IsEmpty(B)
>  
>
>	This gives us an expression that remains valid even if B is substituted 
>for some other cell, so we can rewrite it with a variable:
>
>X = IsMine(LeftOf(p)) AND IsMine(RightOf(p)) AND IsEmpty(p)
>
>  
>
Ok this is now a bit like taking an ANN (or an EP) and scanning across 
all of the boards positions looking for good moves. So like roving eye 
only not roving. A scanning eye. (Getting feelings of Deja vu here).

>(iii) for the overall output, I have assigned each board an additional real 
>value, which is its output weighting.  The overall output of the system is 
>the weighted sum of all generated boards, weighted by their output 
>weighting.  the system is then taken to be choosing the play the cell with 
>the highest value on this output board.
>
>--
>
>	That's the basic idea.  Is anybody completely lost?
>  
>
Sort of. Actually although not central to your post I like the idea of 
exploiting symmetry, the work we were doing manually normalizing TTT 
board state was very specific to the problem at hand. A more generic 
technique for searching out symmetries sounds like a good idea. So e.g. 
when modules are connecting the connection routine could be 
parameterised to connect 'surfaces' of different dimensionality, shape, 
size, rotation etc. in the hope that one of the surfaces described is 
relevant to the problem - so for TTT a 2D surface of size 3x3.

In addition I often wonder if we shouldn't just replace the old style 
neuron with sigmoid activation fn with nodes that apply one of a fixed 
set of functions. A sort of  EP-NEAT fusion, this is basically what I 
was describing a while ago in the discussion about good benchmark 
functions. Does anyone have a good argument for/against this? I suppose 
aligning the input/output value ranges of different functions is one 
problem, but that could be solved by with a bit of normalisation I suspect.

Taking this further I would like to modify the sharpneat framework to be 
made more generic so that EP-NEAT could be defined by slotting an  an 
EP-NEAT node type and any associated  logic/functionality required. 
Standard NEAT with ANN's then becomes one possible implementation of a 
wider technique. Actually Ken makes this point on the NEAT web page 
somehwere - that the topolgy evolvign aspect of NEAT is useful in other 
arena's, not just ANN's.


Colin
